chapter.title: CodeX Site Overview
chapter.para:
CodeX is a &SYS_ORG_NAME; internal Web Site available at http://&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN;/. To browse the CodeX site use your favorite Web Browser
CodeX uses standard HTML and only a little bit of Javascript. It is known to work well with Netscape 4.x, Netscape 6.x and Mozilla as well as IE 4 or 5. Other Web Browsers like Opera or Konqueror work as well. CodeX uses very little graphic material and is therefore browsable by specific text only browser like those used by visually impaired people.. CodeX is a rich site and the CodeX User Guide is going to guide you through all the services that the CodeX site has to offer. In order to help you find your way in the CodeX services gallery, gives a broad overview of the services available as well as a flow chart showing how to access a given service.

section.title: CodeX Home Page
section.para: The Home Page is divided in 4 parts (see ):

step.para: The CodeX Main Menu: on the left hand side of the screen
CodeX Short Introduction: the upper central part gives you a brief but pivotal introduction to the CodeX initiative and a series of links to must read documents
CodeX Latest News: The lower central part shows the last 10 pieces of news related to CodeX hosted projects or to the CodeX site.
The CodeX Dashboard: The right hand side of the home page shows a series of statistics about the overall activity of the CodeX Site

section.title: The CodeX Main Menu
section.para: The CodeX main menu is a permanent piece of information that you'll always see on your screen wherever you are in the CodeX site. Its content can vary according to where you and who you are. In other words it is context sensitive. Let's take 2 examples:

listitem.para: If you are visiting the CodeX site as an anonymous user the upper part of the menu invites you to login or to create a new account whereas if you are logged in you'll be given access to other functions like Logout, Account Maintenance, Personal Page, etc.

Similarly if you decide to visit a given project hosted on CodeX, the menu will offer an additional section giving access to the Project Summary page (the public face of a project) or to the Project Administration page (A reserved view for project members only)

section.para: In the rest of this section we only review those items that are permanent and context independent. Other menu items are described later in the document in the related service description.

section.title: Software Map
section.para: The Software Map is a pivotal service in CodeX that you can (should) use to determine if there are some pieces of software that you can re-use for your own work. The Software Map is one of the 2 ways by which you can search for existing software projects. The other one relies on the Search Facility (See ).
When a project is created it is classified by the project creator according to 7 criteria:

listitem.para: Development Status: How mature your project is (alpha, beta, stable,...)
Environment: in which environment your software is being used (Web, Win32, X Window, text mode,...)
Audience: The target audience of your software (developers, end-users, system administrators,...)
License: License of your software. In most cases this is going to be the &SYS_ORG_NAME; Code exchange Policy
Operating System: Operating system(s) your software runs on
Programming Languages: the programming languages you used to develop your software
Topic: The field of use of your project. This criteria describes the area in which your software operates (Printing, Scanning, Information Technology,...)

section.para: Each criterion can have up to 3 values for a given project (e.g. you can select up to 3 programming languages for a given project). Values of the various criteria are taken from a list of predefined values and most of them are not expected to change in a foreseeable future except for the "Topic" criterion. The "Topic" criterion reflects the domain covered by your project (Printing, Scanning, Information Technology, etc.) and it follows a hierarchy of domains and sub-domains that the CodeX Team constantly refines as more projects are coming.

Using the Software Map you can browse CodeX hosted projects according to any of these criteria. As you explore the map, projects matching the criteria are listed on the screen with their name, description, creation date, activity percentile, and other information. The values of the 7 criteria for a given project are listed right after the project name and description. Notice that next to each criteria value is a [Filter] hyperlink. Clicking on any of these filters will result in restricting the project list to those that match the filter.

A Software Map browsing sample is shown on . In this example, the user has first opened the Programming Languages Criteria and then selected C as a language of choice. This probably led to a large number of projects and so she then decided to narrow the set of projects by specifying 2 additional filters: the first one specifies that the Development Status must be Production-Stable and the second one requires that the projects runs on the SunOS/Solaris operating system.

As a result of this multi-criteria screening, the user ends up with a list of 9 projects (only the first one is shown on to save space). Filters have another interesting property: they are sticky. It means that if you decide to browse the projects from another angle (say by opening the Topic folder), the selected filters will constantly apply. In order to release the search constraint you must explicitly remove the filter by clicking on the [Remove this Filter] link in the upper part of the screen.

tip.title: TIP
tip.para: If you repeatedly execute the same browsing operation on the Software Map you can save it in your Personal Page. To do this, first execute your software map request as explained above and when you are happy with the selection criteria, click on the Bookmark This Page item in the CodeX Main Menu. This will make a new link appear in your Personal Page that you can then edit to give it an appropriate description.

section.title: The Code Snippet Library
section.para: A project hosted on CodeX has the ability to use a large spectrum of services. However not all pieces of software worth sharing require such a rich environment. Sharing a very short piece of source code like a macro, a function or a shell script has to be quick and easy. This is precisely the role of the Code Snippet Library.

section.title: Code Snippet Browsing
section.para: The welcome page of the Code Snippet Library classifies the code snippets by category and by programming languages. The figures next to each label indicate the number of code snippets available in each category.
You can browse code snippets in 2 different ways:

listitem.para: Navigate through the categories or programming languages classification
Use the Search box in the CodeX Main menu on the left hand side of the screen. Keywords typed are search in the code snippet title and in the code snippet description.

section.para: Matching snippets are shown in a list along with their code snippet ID number, title and detailed description as well as the author's name. Please note that by clicking on the author's name you can immediately send a question or a suggestion to the author of the code snippet.

figure.title: List of Code Snippets in the 'HTML Manipulation' category

section.title: Code Snippet Submission
section.para: To submit a new code snippet click on the "Submit a new Code Snippet" link in the Code Snippet Menu at the top of the screen. Provide the code snippet title and description. You can use Web locations (URLs) in these two fields. CodeX will automatically turn them into hyperlinks in the final version. Also provide the code snippet type, programming language and category as requested. Should a category or a programming language be missing when you submit a new code snippet please contact the CodeX team by clicking on the link right below the pull-down menus.

It is highly recommended that you provide a version number as well. This version number is a free text field and can have any kind of value. Using a version number is useful if you want to post a newer version in the future. We also recommend that you indicate the same version number in the source code associated with the snippet so that CodeX users can determine whether they already have the latest version the next time they visit the Code Snippet Library.

The code snippet itself can be submitted either by simply copy-pasting the source code in the text area or by uploading a file. We do recommend that you copy-paste the source code to make it directly visible when users browse the Code Snippet library.

However there are cases where it is ok to upload non human readable files. Typical examples are when your code snippet is a made of several files that you may want to deliver in the form of an archive (zip or compressed tar). Another example is when the code snippet is not human readable: simulation software (e.g. LabView) use proprietary and non human readable format for their source files. In any case do not post pure binary code like compiled C, C++,Java,... The Code Snippet Library, like CodeX, is about sharing and reusing software code not binary.

section.title: Updating a Code Snippet
section.para: To update a code snippet with a newer version of the source code, select the original code snippet either by browsing the code snippet category or by using the search mechanism. Click on the Code Snippet in the result list and proceed to the "Submit a new version" link at the end of the screen. Provide a change description, a new version number and copy-paste the source code associated with the new version.

note.para: Please note that even though this is still the same code snippet, CodeX assigns a new code snippet ID number to each version. So referencing a new version in a Code Snippet Package (see section Grouping Code Snippets below) will require that you delete the old version and add the new one.

section.title: Deleting a Code Snippet
section.para: Select the code snippet as indicated above. Then click on the appropriate code snippet in the result list. From here you can click on the waste basket icon () next to the code snippet version to delete one or several versions of the code snippet.

section.title: Grouping Code Snippets
section.para: If you have submitted several code snippets that relate to the same topic, are written in the same language and belong to the same code snippet category it might be a good idea to group them together under a common umbrella. This is what Code Snippet Packages are for.

To create a code snippet package click on the "Create a Package" item in the Code Snippet Menu at the top of the screen. Provide a title, a description, type, category and version as requested. After you submit the form, a new window will pop up asking you for the ID numbers of the Code Snippets that must be added to the package. So before you create a package make sure you have the code snippet ID numbers available.

section.title: Updating a Code Snippet Package
section.para: Like code snippets, packages can be updated. To update a package just proceed as for an ordinary code snippet. First search for it, select it and finally click in the Edit icon. From here you can add/delete code snippet to/from the package. If you want to update the package with a new version of a code snippet, first delete the old version and add the new one which has its own specific code snippet ID (see "Updating a Code Snippet" above).

section.title: New Releases
section.para: Click on this menu item to see a list of the most recent software releases (also known as new versions) that have been posted on the CodeX site by the various projects. If you want to keep aware of new incoming releases visit this page on a regular basis. CodeX also allows you to monitor the new software releases posted by a given project. To do so go to the Project Summary page of this project by clicking on the project title and then select the monitor icon () next to the release name. Once you monitor a project release, e-mail notification will be sent to you whenever the project team posts a new software release.

section.title: Site Documentation
section.para: The Site Documentation pointer is the entry point to the CodeX documentation. The CodeX documentation is entirely managed via the Document Manager (see ) service of the CodeX project, which is of course hosted on CodeX. The documents on this page cover all the CodeX site. It includes presentation material, the user guide and other important documents. Read them carefully.

important.title: ** Important Note **
important.para:
The &SYS_ORG_NAME; Code exchange Policy
[XCEP] is available in the Must Read Documents section. This 2-page Corporate Policy governs the act of Software Sharing at &SYS_ORG_NAME;. All CodeX users must read, understand and apply this policy before re-using software or hosting any of their projects on the CodeX site. CodeX gives you direct access to the Intellectual Property of your company and you must therefore make sure that you and your group strictly conforms to the Code eXchange Policy for the benefit of the entire company. Failing to comply with the terms of the Code eXchange Policy can lead to severe disciplinary actions including prosecution and contract termination.

section.title: CodeX Developers Channels
section.para: One of the top priority objectives of the CodeX site is to become a discussion forum for the software developers regardless of the organization they belong to and the country they work in.

To this end the CodeX Team has created a series of mailing lists (called Developers Channels) where anybody, including non-CodeX users, can subscribe. Each channel is dedicated to a given software related topic. The creation of a new channel is under the responsibility of the CodeX Team. If you want to create a new developers channel please contact the CodeX Team at codex-contact@&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN;.
The Developers Channels managed on CodeX have a certain number of advantages over conventional distribution lists:

listitem.para: Subscription and Un-subscription are entirely user driven and it can be done through the CodeX Web interface without any assistance.
All messages posted to the channel are archived forever and can be browsed at any time. (In the future they will probably be searchable as well)
Subscribers can decide to receive digests from the mailing list rather than individual messages.

section.title: CodeX Discussion Forums
section.para: Discussion Forums are an alternate way to keep in touch with the CodeX community. The CodeX Discussion Forums were created primarily as a communication vehicle between the CodeX users and the CodeX Team. These are general purpose Forums where you can ask for Help with CodeX, suggest new features, new categories for the software map, etc.

These Forums are entirely Web based which means that you have to use the CodeX Web interface to post and read user messages. However Forums also offer the ability to be monitored, which means that all traffic will be sent to you via e-mail.

tip.title: Tip: Don't let your software licenses take the dust
tip.para: One of the Forums available on CodeX is called Software Bazaar. This Forum was put in place to buy or sell unused 3rd party software from other project teams. It is often the case that software packages acquired by a project team are no longer needed after some time. We wanted to give other people a chance to get the unused license rather than buying yet another one. Similarly this Forum is the place to announce an Enterprise-Wide license obtained by your group and that other people could benefit from.

section.title: Project Help Wanted
section.para: As you will see later in this document, each CodeX project has the ability to post jobs. This minimal job posting system is particularly well suited to publish call for expertise. By clicking on this item you'll see all job posting requests awaiting help from the community. Visit this section on a regular basis if you want to help others in the corporation solve their technical problems.
For more details on how to post jobs see .

section.title: Contact Us
section.para: In addition to the Discussion Forums, you can always use the "Contact Us" link at the bottom of the CodeX Main Menu to get in touch with the CodeX Team. Our team works in 3 distinct time zones so it is very likely that whatever time of the day it is, you'll have a quick reply to your message.
Do not hesitate to bug the "Contact Us" link. We are here to help.

section.title: The Search Facility
section.para: This is the last item in the CodeX Main Menu but not the least. CodeX allows you to search almost any piece of CodeX information through a keyword search mechanism. When you are on the CodeX Home Page you can search for keywords in the following resources:

listitem.para: Software Projects: a match is attempted with project names as well as their short and long description. This search mechanism is very complementary with the Software Map.

Code Snippet Library: Code snippets are small pieces of code that you can post on CodeX (see ) along with a description. You can search this description by keywords are see if there are code snippets that you can re-use to ease your job.
People: keywords will be searched in the CodeX user database and matched against the user's login name, real name and e-mail address.
Bugs: If you enter the bug tracking system if any CodeX project, the Bugs item will show up in the search box, allowing you to actually search the bug database of this project.

section.title: The CodeX Dashboard
section.para: The CodeX Dashboard resides on the right hand side of the CodeX Home Page. It is a sort of a fish-eye view of the global CodeX activity. Several indicators are available:

listitem.para: CodeX Statistics: give the total number of hosted projects (excluding those that have a private status), the total number of registered users, the total number of software packages downloaded and the total number of Web pages browsed by CodeX users since the site opening.
Top Project Downloads: shows which software projects were downloaded the day before (based on midnight EST time) and how many times.
Newest Projects: the last 10 registered projects. Looking at this part of the dashboard on a regular basis will help you to keep informed on the new projects hosted on CodeX.

Most Active This Week: the 20 most active projects over the past 7 days on a scale from 0 to 100%. The magic formula that we use behind the scene to compute this ranking is a weighted sum of the activity observed in the various projects services. It takes many things into account: the number of commits/updates on the CVS repository, the number of bugs and tasks submitted or modified, the number of file releases, etc. Looking at this list is an excellent way to see which projects are actively working on CodeX.

section.para: As a conclusion, we strongly advise you to visit the CodeX Home Page on a regular basis for it gives you an excellent idea of what is going in terms of software development across &SYS_ORG_NAME;.
Bottom line: Make CodeX your browser home page :-)
